facts: A map is a flat drawing that represents places on Earth and uses symbols to show features like roads, rivers, and cities.
A map scale tells how distances on the map compare to real distances, such as 1 inch on the map equaling 10 miles in real life.
The four main directions on most maps are north, south, east, and west, often shown with a compass rose.
Latitude lines run east to west and measure how far north or south a place is from the Equator.
Longitude lines run north to south and measure how far east or west a place is from the Prime Meridian.
A legend (or key) explains what the mapâ€™s symbols and colors mean so you can understand what you are seeing.
Because Earth is round, every flat map projection distorts something, such as size, shape, distance, or direction.
